content.raw: In case you want one, Simbody has a comprehensive inertia validator [here](https://github.com/simbody/simbody/blob/master/SimTKcommon/Mechanics/include/SimTKcommon/internal/MassProperties.h#L526). It includes obscure requirements on the off-diagonal elements also, kindly provided by Paul Mitiguy. (`SignificantReal` is about 1e-14 in double precision; `getEps()` returns machine precision, about 1e-16.)
content.html: In case you want one, Simbody has a comprehensive inertia validator here. It includes obscure requirements on the off-diagonal elements also, kindly provided by Paul Mitiguy. (SignificantReal is about 1e-14 in double precision; getEps() returns machine precision, about 1e-16.)

content.raw:
Thanks for the good explanation. 
Now that my understanding of the AddForce*/AddTorque methods semantics is clearer, I guess that It is possible to apply an arbitrary wrench by decomposing it in a pure force and torque on its Poinsot Axis. The obtained pure force and pure torque can then be applied to the link, with the force that is applied to a point belonging to the Poinsot Axis.
content.html: Thanks for the good explanation. Now that my understanding of the AddForce*/AddTorque methods semantics is clearer, I guess that It is possible to apply an arbitrary wrench by decomposing it in a pure force and torque on its Poinsot Axis. The obtained pure force and pure torque can then be applied to the link, with the force that is applied to a point belonging to the Poinsot Axis.

pull_request.title: fix Link::AddTorque for Simbody and Bullet, with test

pullrequest.title: fix Link::AddTorque for Simbody and Bullet, with test

content.raw:
I think you are both saying the same thing, despite appearances. If you apply a torque alone, there is no reference point. If you apply a lone force at a point, there is of course that point to specify, and no torque is applied. However, if you decide to shift the specification of the force to somewhere other than the point at which it was applied (such as at the body origin or COM) then a moment r X f is generated where r is the vector from where the force was actually applied to where you are expressing it. Thus to specify a pure force away from its application point you would have to apply (force,torque)=(f, r X f) making it appear as though the torque is associated with a point.

So to be precise: `AddForce` must take a force vector (typically expressed in the world frame) and an application point (typically expressed in the link frame). `AddTorque` should take only a torque vector in the world frame. If you then look under the covers at the accumulated forces and torque for a given link, you will see that the total force is just the sum of all the given force vectors, but the total torque is the sum of the torque vectors *plus* r X f moments generated by each of the forces at their application points.
content.html:
I think you are both saying the same thing, despite appearances. If you apply a torque alone, there is no reference point. If you apply a lone force at a point, there is of course that point to specify, and no torque is applied. However, if you decide to shift the specification of the force to somewhere other than the point at which it was applied (such as at the body origin or COM) then a moment r X f is generated where r is the vector from where the force was actually applied to where you are expressing it. Thus to specify a pure force away from its application point you would have to apply (force,torque)=(f, r X f) making it appear as though the torque is associated with a point.

So to be precise: AddForce must take a force vector (typically expressed in the world frame) and an application point (typically expressed in the link frame). AddTorque should take only a torque vector in the world frame. If you then look under the covers at the accumulated forces and torque for a given link, you will see that the total force is just the sum of all the given force vectors, but the total torque is the sum of the torque vectors plus r X f moments generated by each of the forces at their application points.

pullrequest.title: fix Link::AddTorque for Simbody and Bullet, with test

content.raw:
I agree for pure couples, but apparently If I want to add a wrench (force-moment) to a link in Gazebo I have to jointly use the functions `AddForce` and `AddTorque`.

In this case the angular part of the wrench (the one that I will pass to `AddTorque`) will depend on the point with respect to which I am expressing the wrench, while the linear part (the  "force") will be expression point indipendent.
content.html:
I agree for pure couples, but apparently If I want to add a wrench (force-moment) to a link in Gazebo I have to jointly use the functions AddForce and AddTorque.

In this case the angular part of the wrench (the one that I will pass to AddTorque) will depend on the point with respect to which I am expressing the wrench, while the linear part (the "force") will be expression point indipendent.

content.raw: It's late in my time zone, so I should probably sleep on it before responding, but I think the reference point doesn't matter for application of a pure torque. The coordinate frame matters for interpreting the `x,y,z` components, and the reference point definitely matters for forces and force-moment couples, but I don't think pure torques have a reference point.
content.html: It's late in my time zone, so I should probably sleep on it before responding, but I think the reference point doesn't matter for application of a pure torque. The coordinate frame matters for interpreting the x,y,z components, and the reference point definitely matters for forces and force-moment couples, but I don't think pure torques have a reference point.

content.raw:
Just a curiosity as we are using this function: with respect to which point the added torque is expressed ? 
Looking at the implementation it appears that for simbody is expressed with respect to the link origin [1] while for ODE is expressed with respect to the link center of mass [2].

[1] : https://simtk.org/api_docs/simbody/api_docs33/Simbody/html/classSimTK_1_1Force_1_1DiscreteForces.html#a0305a15e584e27af583fc0c5243a7925 

[2] : http://robotics.naist.jp/~akihiko-y/doxy/ode0.10/group__bodies.html#g8378560dd168ee8d7a4b74e3de510ebc
content.html:
Just a curiosity as we are using this function: with respect to which point the added torque is expressed ? Looking at the implementation it appears that for simbody is expressed with respect to the link origin [1] while for ODE is expressed with respect to the link center of mass [2].

[1] : https://simtk.org/api_docs/simbody/api_docs33/Simbody/html/classSimTK_1_1Force_1_1DiscreteForces.html#a0305a15e584e27af583fc0c5243a7925

[2] : http://robotics.naist.jp/~akihiko-y/doxy/ode0.10/group__bodies.html#g8378560dd168ee8d7a4b74e3de510ebc
